para.emphasis: This class is used to gather all the information from the input file and store it in a static object available to all processes.

literallayout.computeroutput: 1 #ifndef ParameterReaderFlag 2 #define ParameterReaderFlag 3 4 #include <deal.II/base/parameter_handler.h> 5 #include "../Core/Waveguide.h" 6 using namespace dealii; 7 8 /** 9 * \class ParameterReader 10 * \brief This class is used to gather all the information from the input file 11 *and store it in a static object available to all processes. 12 * 13 * The ParameterReader is a very useful tool. It uses a deal-function to read a 14 *xml-file and parse the contents to specific variables. These variables have 15 *default values used in their declaration. The members of this class do two 16 *things: 17 * -# declare the variables. This includes setting a data-type for them and a 18 *default value should none be provided in the input file. Furthermore there can 19 *be restrictions like maximum or minimum values etc. 20 * -# call an external function to parse an input-file. 21 * 22 * After creating an object of this type and calling both declare() and read(), 23 *this object contains all the information from the input file and can be used 24 *in the code without dealing with persistence. 25 * 26 *\author Pascal Kraft 27 *\date 23.11.2015 28 */ 29 class ParameterReader : public Subscriptor { 30 public: 31 /** 32 * Deal Offers the ParameterHandler object wich contains all of the 33 * parsing-functionality. An object of that type is included in this one. This 34 * constructor simply uses a copy-constructor to initialize it. 35 */ 36 ParameterReader(ParameterHandler &prmhandler); 37 38 /** 39 * This member calls the read_input_from_xml()-function of the contained 40 * ParameterHandler and this replaces the default values with the values in 41 * the input file. 42 */ 43 void read_parameters(const std::string inputfile); 44 45 /** 46 * In this function, we add all values descriptions to the parameter-handler. 47 * This includes 48 * -# a default value, 49 * -# a data-type, 50 * -# possible restrictions (greater than zero etc.), 51 * -# a description, which is displayed in deals ParameterGUI-tool, 52 * -# a hierarchical structure to order the variables. 53 * 54 * Deals Parameter-GUI can be installed at build-time of the library and 55 * offers a great and easy way to edit the input file. It displays appropriate 56 * input-methods depending on the type, so, for example, in case of a 57 * selection from three different values (i.e. the name of a solver that has 58 * to either be GMRES, MINRES or UMFPACK) it displays a dropdown containing 59 * all the options. 60 */ 61 void declare_parameters(); 62 63 private: 64 ParameterHandler &prm; 65 }; 66 67 #endif
